titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxvi — no.22 Richmond, Va. Tuesday, January 26, 1864 Price one cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.

row.cell: 1 square, 1 day,
1 square, 5 days,
1 square, 2 days
1 square, 5 days,
1 square 3 days
1 square, 12 days,
1 square 4 days
1 square, 1 month,

div1.p: Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: 200 dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on the 19th inst, my boy Austen.
The said boy is about 16 years old, about five feet high, and of a light brown complexion.
He took with him my dark bay horse, small in nine, but compact and in good order.
Austen has a high forehead but narrow, and his hair extends very low on either side.
The above reward will be paid for his delivery to Messrs Lee & Bowman, in Richmond, or secured in any jail, and the recovery of the horse.

div3.head: 50 dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will give $50 for any information that will lead to the recovery of a small black Mare, quite lame in the right bold leg, shoulder very sore, has a white spot in her forehead, and unshod, except the lame foot.
She stsayed or was stolen from my house, near the City Spring, on 8th street. She was heard from near Old Church, Hanover county.
All expenses will be paid for her return, with the reward.
100 dollars reward for the delivery to me of Sims, 26 years old, slender, with high forehead, dark mulatto, who left yesterday, supposed with troops for Petersburg.

div3.head: 25 reward.
div3.p: --Will be paid for the detection of the scoundrel who entered my house about 1 o'clock yesterday, in my absence, and slapped my servant boy.
div3.closer:
W. T. Richeson.
188 Main street. ja 26--1t

div3.head: 1.000 dollars reward.
div3.p: --Left my house on Saturday evening Jan'y 23d, shortly after six o'clock, my two servants, Matilda and Lavinia.
Matilda is a very stout woman, about 5 feet high, black complexion, smooth, pleasant features, has scars on her arms, neck, and head, and is about 38 years old.
Javinia is a small, medium height woman, black complexion, sharp features, has scars on her arms from sores, and is 21 years old.

Both are supposed to be trying to make their way to the peninsula in company with other negroes, as they are known to have left with Mr. Solomon Davis's servant girl.
The above reward will be paid to any one for the apprehension of both, or $500 a piece for their delivery to me at my house, or where I can get possession of them.
div3.closer:
Wm. Thalhimer,
No. 231 Broad st, bet 3d and 4th. ja 25--2t*

div3.head: Five hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away, my boy Barrett.
He is 23 or 24 years of age; 5 feet for 3 inches high; has the thumb cut off of the left hand; was seen at Ashland some three weeks ago. A reward of five hundred dollars will be given if delivered to me at Roanoke Station. Richmond and Danville Railroad, or confined in jail so that I can get him.
div3.closer:
Jno. M. White,
Talcott P. O. Charlotte co, Va. ja 25--10t

div3.head: 200 dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away, on Sunday night, the 17th inst, my negro man James; he is about 22 years old, quite likely, with smooth skin, black complexion, full suit of hair, 5 feet 7 or 8 inches high, weighs about 150 pounds, and with his index finger on his right hand stiff.
In attempting to make his escape he will do biless pass through Richmond as his mother lives there with Mr. Wm. R. Pugh, on Grace street, between 7th and 8th. The above reward will be paid on his apprehension and confinement in jail so that I get him.
div3.closer:
Wm. E. Green.
Mossinsford, Charlotte co, Va. ja 21--12t*

div3.p:
twenty-five dollars reward for the delivery to me, in the City of Richmond, I. J. co He is about 25 years old, bright mulatto, who left Friday morning, the 22d.
He is supposed to be turning about Richmond, or he may be in Hanover where he was hired last year.

div3.head: 500 dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the delivery to me or securing so that I can get them, two negro men belonging to Mrs. Elizabeth Hises Adam, 6 feet high, very black, with thick lips left on the evening of the first of January.
Peter, 5 feet 8 inches high, brown skin, thick lips, with some impediment in his speech, left Monday, the 18th of January.
It is supposed that both are making for the lines of the enemy.
$150 for the recovery of either one will be given.
div3.closer:
Charles S. Bruce,
Head of 17th st. ja 21--10t*

div3.head: Three hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
Will be paid for the delivery to me, or securing so that I get them, three mulatto slaves, Maris Martha and Emily, belonging to the estate of Wm. Munford, dec'd, of $100 for either.
They left my residence in this city, last evening Maris is about 36 and is the mother of Martha, 18, and Emily 16 years of age.
John Hicks, a free mulatto and barber of this city is the husband of Maria, and is said to have left the city a week ten days ago. It is supposed that they are all making for the lines of the enemy.

div3.head: By the Governor of Virginia.--a Proclamation.

div4.p: --Information having been received by the Executive that Josiah and Toby Oliver, who were confined in the jail of Charlotte county under a charge of felony, escaped therefrom on the morning of the 3d January, and are now going at large: Therefore, I do hereby offer a reward of two hundred dollars to any person or persons who shall arrest the said Josiah and Toby Oliver, and deliver them into the jail of Charlotte county, or one hundred dollars for such arrest and delivery of either of them; and I do moreover require all officers of this Commonwealth, civil and military, and request the people generally, to use their best exertions to procure the arrest of the said Josiah and Toby Oliver, that they may be brought to justice.
Given under my hand as Governor, and under the Lesser Seal of the Commonwealth, at Richmond, this 15th day of January in the year 1864.
div4.closer:
Wm. Smith.
Teste: George W. Monford,
Secretary of the Commonwealth.

div4.p: Josiah Oliver is 24 or 25 years old, about 5 feet 6 or 8 inches high, weighs 135 or 140 pounds, and has dark hair and whiskers.
Toby Oliver is 23 or 24 years of age, 5 feet 3 or 4 inches high, weighs about 125 or 130 pounds, and has dark hair, without beard.

div3.head: By the Governor of Virginia.--a Proclamation.

div4.p:
--Information having been received by the Executive that E Hodson Moorefield, who was confined in the jail of Charlotte county under a charge of felony, escaped the reform on the night of the 24th December, 1863, and is now going at large: Therefore, I do hereby offer a reward of one hundred dollars to any person or persons who shall arrest the said Moorefield and deliver him into the jail of Charlotte county.
And I do moreover require all officers of this Commonwealth, civil and military, and request the people generally, to use their best exertions to procure the arrest of the said Moorefield, that he may be brought to justice.
Given under my hand as Governor of Virginia, and under the Lesser Seal of the Commonwealth, at Richmond, this 15th day of January, in the year 1864.
div4.closer:
Wm. Smith.
Teste: Geo. W. Munford,
Secretary of Commonwealth.

div4.p: E. Dodson Moorefield represented himself to be about 18 or 19 years of age, is about 5 feet 2 or 2 inches high, has light hair and fair complexion, and weighs about 118 or 120 pounds.

--A Proclamation.--Information having been received by the Executive that Pleasant, a slave, the property of Theodorick Carter, Sr, who was confined in the jail of Appomattox county, under sentence of death for the murder of Wm. V. Hotley, has made his escape from the said jail and is now going at large: Therefore, I do hereby offer a reward of two hundred dollars to any person or persons who shall arrest the said slave Pleasant and deliver him into the jail of said county of Appomattox; and I do moreover require all officers of this Commonwealth, civil and military, and request the people generally, to use their best exertions to procure the arrest of the said Pleasant, that he may be brought to justice.
Given under my hand as Governor, and under the Lesser Seal of the Commonwealth, at Richmond, this 15th day of January, in the year 1864.
div4.closer:
Wm. Smith.
By the Governor.
Geo. W. Munford,
Sec'y of the Commonwealth.

div4.p: Pleasant is a dark mulatto, about 30 years of age, 5 feet 10 inches high, and heavy built.

div3.head: Recruits Wanted
div3.p:
--For Major Harry Gamer's battalion of independent cavalry.
Horses, equipments, &c; furnished, and $50 bounty.
Apply at once at our office, corner Main and 6th streets, opposite Spotswood Hotel.

div3.head: Conscripts.
div3.p: --Persons table to conscription, unwilling to go into the army, can hear of a meeting to their advantage by addressing "Civilian," at this office.

div3.head: Second Company, Richmond, howitzers
div3.p:
--Persons desiring to join this company, Capt. David Watson, will apply to the undersigned, who will grant furloughs until the 10th February next.--Volunteers received until the maximum is reached.
The company is now attached to the 1st Virginia artillery, reserve of Ewell's corps, in winter quarters at Frederick Hall Depot Louisa co, Va.
div3.closer:
Sergt Reuben B. Pleasants.
10 Pearl st, up stairs. ja 23--12t*

div3.head: Confiscation of property in Norfolk.
div3.p:
The humane Butler, who is so solicitous about the health of the Yankee prisoners in Richmond, has commenced confiscating the property of citizens in Norfolk.
The real estate, furniture, goods, chattels, and personal property of the following persons is advertised for sale for the benefit of the U. S. Government: Wm. W. Davis, C. W. Murdaugh, member of the Legislature; Jos. M. Miles, clothing merchant; Rev. Thos. Hume, Baptist minister; Ed. Kearns, a captain in the Confederate service; Thos. W. Cofer, John T. Rustic, naval constructor at Selma' Ala; W. C. Wingfield, C. W. Young, Robert V. Boykin, John De Bree, Chas. T. Myers, W. M. Mahone, Mathias Ward, and Terry Sinclair.

div3.head: Confederate States Congress.
div3.p: The Senate was called to order, and opened with prayer by the Rev. Mr. Baker, of the Presbyterian Church.

The bill to authorize the creditors of the Confederate States to receive their dues in 8 per cent. bonds, and the bill to authorize the issue of certain bonds, and make the coupons attached a legal tender for the payment of debts, were reported back adversely from the Finance Committee.
Mr. Sparrow, from the Military Committee, reported, with the recommendation that it pass, the House bill to establish an asylum for wounded and disabled soldiers.
Mr. Sparrow, from the same committee, reported back favorably the bill to confer additional powers on military courts and court-martial, and the bill to amend the act to organize military courts.
Mr. Sparrow, from the Military Committee, reported a bill to amend the 65th article of war, and a bill to provide and organize a general staff for the armies in the field to serve during the war.

Mr. Phelan introduced a bill to amend the act to punish drunkenness in the army.
Referred to the Military Committee.

The Chair laid before the Senate a communication from the Secretary of the Treasury in response to a resolution of the Senate requesting to be informed of the amount of the funded debt of the Confederate States on the 1st of January, 1864; the amount of non-interest bearing notes outstanding on the 1st Jan., 1864, &c.
According to the Secretary's statements it appears that the funded debt of the Confederate States, on the 1st Jan., 1864, was--

row.cell: In eight per cent. bonds under act of Feb. 28, 1861
In eight per cent. bonds under act of May 16, 1861,
In eight per cent bonds under act of Aug. 19, 1861,
In eight per cent. bonds under act of April 12, 1862,
In eight per cent. bonds under act of Feb. 20, 1863,
In seven per cent. bonds under act of Feb. 20, 1863,
In six per cent. bonds under act of March 23d, 1863,
In cotton interest coupon bonds,
The amount of call certificates outstanding 1st Jan., 1864, was
The amount or non-interest bearing Treasury notes,
The amount of interest bearing Treasury notes,
The amount of Treasury notes under the denomination of five dollars,

div3.p: The communication and accompanying documents were ordered to be printed.
The Senate then went into secret session, and the doors being reopened--

The Senate resumed the consideration of the bill declaring persons owing military service to the Confederate States, and who seek to avoid such service by removing beyond the control and jurisdiction of said States, alien enemies, and subjecting their property to confiscation.
After a long discussion, the bill was recommitted to the Judiciary Committee.
The bill to provide for a new issue of Treasury notes, and for funding the Treasury notes now outstanding, was, on motion of Mr. Semmes, indefinitely postponed.
On motion, the Senate again resolved itself into secret session.
The House met at 11 o'clock, and was opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. Burrows.

The Senate bill to regulate the collection of the tax in kind on tobacco, and to amend the act to lay taxes for the public defence and to carry on the Government, approved April 24, 1863, was taken up under a suspension of the rules, and without amendment considered and passed.

A resolution was offered by Mr. Gartrell, of Georgia, to instruct the Doorkeeper to furnish the President and Heads of Departments with the documents ordered to be printed by the House.
Agreed to.

Mr. Chilton, of Ala., from the Post-Office Committee, reported a bill for the appointment of an agent for the Post-Office Department, and such clerks as may be necessary to carry on the postal service in the States west of the Misissippi. The rules were suspended, and the bill taken up and passed.

Mr. Barksdale, of Miss, offered a resolution that the President be requested to inform the House what steps have been taken to carry out the provisions of the act of 13th of October, chapter 62, in relation to the arrest and disposition of slaves who who have been recaptured from the enemy; what number of depots for their safekeeping have been established, and whether public notice has been given in the newspapers of their arrest, as provided in said act. Agreed to.

Mr. Foote, of Tenn., offered a resolution, which was rejected, that the bill to continue in service all troops now in the military service of the Confederate States, be hereafter considered in open session.

Mr. Lyons, of Virginia, from the Committee to whom was referred the charge of corruption against a member of the House, contained in a paragraph in the Richmond Examiner, of the 7th day of January, reported that the committee have carefully examined every witness and source of information indicated to them, or which suggested itself, and was within their control, and have found nothing to sustain the charge.

Mr. Foote, of Tenn., offered a resolution that, in the judgment of this House, it is eminently desirable, in order to secure the comfortable subsistence of our Valliant armies, and to allay existing discontents known to exist in certain rural districts, that the present Commissary General should be removed, and a suitable successor appointed in his place.
Mr. Kenan, of Ga., moved to lay the resolution on the table, and on this motion the ayes and noes were had, and resulted — ayes 46, noes 20.

Mr. Chilton, of Ala., offered a resolution that the Committee on Claims inquire whether provision should not be made by law for auditing and paying accounts against the Government for horses impressed and actually received into the service of the Confederate States, but which have been rejected by the pay department on account of some informality in the appointment of impressing officers, or in the certificates of the officers making such impressment, and that they report by bill or otherwise.

Mr. Gartrell, from the Judiciary Committee, reported back Senate bill fixing the regular time of the meeting of Congress on the first of May, with a recommendation that the House concur in the bill as passed by the Senate.
Mr. Atkins, of Tenn., moved to amend the bill by striking out the 1st of May and inserting the words "19th of February."
Mr. Hilton, of Fla, moved to postpone the further consideration of the bill until the 15th of February. The motion did not prevail.
On motion, the House went into secret session.

div3.head: The Legislature.
div3.p: Senate.--One bill was introduced in the Senate yesterday, making debts due to branch banks within the enemy's lines payable to the mother banks within Confederate lines.
Mr. Douglas proposed a preamble and joint resolution defining the law now existing and declaring militia officers not exempt from conscription.
A communication was received from Gov. Smith in regard to the reserve State force, &c.
The militia bill was considered until the hour of adjournment.
House.--A bill was reported yesterday for regulating the charges of the Southern Express Company.
Also, a bill authorizing a connection between the Richmond and Petersburg and the Richmond and Fredericksburg Railroad Companies.

And a bill to make Church river a lawful fence through Scott county.
Adjourned.
We are indebted to the signal corps officer for the use of a Baltimore paper of Tuesday last, the 19th inst. We give a summary of the news contained:

div4.head: Proceedings in the Yankee Congress.
div4.p:
In the Yankee House of Representatives on the 18th, Mr. Dawson.
(Democrat,) of Pennsylvania, offered resolutions declaring that the war was not waged for conquest or oppression, and requesting the President to issue a proclamation making known that when any State, now in insurrection, shall submit to the Federal Government, all hostilities against her shall cease, and such State shall be protected against all Interference with her local laws and institutions.
The resolutions were laid on the table — ayes 79, noes 58.

Mr. Cox of Ohio, offered a resolution proposing to take the exchange of prisoners out of the hands of Gen. Butler, and refer it to a Board of Commissioners.
The resolution was summarily laid on the table by a vote of ayes 91, nays 56.
The Senate resolution providing for the appointment of a select committee, consisting of three members of the Senate and five of the House, on the conduct and expenditures of the war, was passed.

Mr. Smith, of Ky., offered resolutions declaring that the rebellion is "desperate, wicked, and bloody;" that "the safety and security of personal and national liberties depend upon its utter and absolute extinction;" and that, therefore, "It is the political, civil, moral, and sacred duty of the people to meet it, fight it, and forever destroy it, thereby establishing perfect and unalterable liberty." The resolutions were adopted — ayes 112, nays 16.

In the Senate, on the 16th, the one million men bill, to release the prisoners at Richmond was discussed.
Mr. Howe, who offered the bill, assured the Senate he was in earnest.
Mr. Trumbull thought one hundred thousand might be raised, but a million was driving it a little too strong.
Mr. Wilson thought a hundred thousand recruits against Lee's veterans would stand no chance at all. The subject was dropped.

In the Senate, on the 18th, a bill was submitted and referred, providing for the establishment of a Bureau of Emancipation, under the Secretary of the Treasury.
The resolution for the expulsion of Senator Davis, of Ky., was referred to the Judiciary Committee.
Joint resolutions of thanks to Hooker, Meade, Howard, Banks, and Burnside, were passed.

div4.head: Awful disaster in child Cathedral destroyed by fire--two thousand women burnt to death.
div4.p:
An awful disaster occurred in Santiago, the capital of Chili, on the 8th of December. The Immaculate Conception was being celebrated in the church of the Jesuits.
It was about 7 o'clock in the evening and the crescent of light (gas) that formed the pedestal for the Virgin Mary fired the wood upon which it rested, and the flames sprung wildly over the building.
There were ten thousand persons in the church.
The suddenness of the fire was awful.
The dense mass of women frightened out of their senses, numbers fainting, and all entangled by their long swelling dresses, rushed as those who knew that death was at their heels, to the one door, which soon became choked up. Fire was everywhere.
Streaming along the wooden ceiling it flung the camphene lamps hung in rows there, among the struggling women.

In a moment the gorgeous church was a sea of flame.
Michael Angell's fearful picture of hell was there but exceeded.
Help was all but impossible.
A Hercules might have strained his strength in vain to pull one from the series mass of frenzied wretches who piled one above another as they climbed over to reach the air, wildly fastening the grip of death upon any one escaping, in order that they might be dragged out with them.
Women seized in the embrace of the flames were seen to undergo a transformation as though by an optical delusion--first dazzling bright, then horribly lean and shrunk up, then black statues rigidly fixed in a writhing attitude.
The fire, Imprisoned by the immense thickness of the walls, had devoured everything combustible by 10 o'clock, and then, defying the sickening stench, people came to look for their lost ones.
The silence, after the piercing screams of the burning were hushed in death, was horrible.
It was the silence of the grave, unbroken but by the bitter wall or fainting cry. Over two thousand souls had leaped through that ordeal of fire to the judgment seat of God.

The writer referring to the fire handles the clergy in the most severe manner, and says the population of Santiago are fired with indescribable indignation at the monstrous conduct of the priests, holding them guilty of the death of all these victims, and particularly the mountebank Ugarte, the inventor of the "Virgins' Post-Office" imposture, which required a countless number of lights, pasteboard scenery, &c.

When the fire broke out they blocked up the door of the sacristy, to devote themselves more undisturbed to saving their "gimeracks." They saved a gilt image, some wooden saints, chalices, and a great deal of sacred matting.
After saving their trash they fled away, except one priest, who favored the agonized victims with his absolution.

More than 500 persons of the highest caste perished, the greater part young girls between fifteen and twenty years of age. One mother perished with her five daughters.
Two thirds of the victims were servants.
Several houses have been noticed by the police as empty, because all their inmales have perished.

The latest information is that 1,700 bodies have been recognized.
Three thousand at least were in the building, and it is not yet known how many have escaped.

div4.head: Reported Plot to capture Johnson's Island.
div4.p:
A dispatch from Sandusky, Ohio, dated the 17th, says that a scout had just returned from a thorough reconnaissance towards Point Pelee, Canada, and reports two or three thousand rebels at Point Pelee, preparatory to a dash upon Johnson's Island.
The strictest vigilance is maintained on the island, and several batteries are in position.
Point Pelee is thirty miles from Johnson's Island.
John Brown, a son of "old John Brown," who resides on Put- in Bay Island, has gone to Columbus to induce the Government to furnish howitzers and small arms for the protection of its inhabitants.
The long roll is frequently sounded.
It is apprehended that the rebels will attempt to cross on the ice.

div4.head: From the army of the Potomac.
div4.p:
A dispatch to the New York Tribune, from the Army of the Potomac, dated January 17th, says that on the evening of the 14th, a squad of the 1st Rhode Island cavalry on picket near Three-Mile Station, were attacked by a body of Rebel cavalry, estimated at 200.
The pickets were forced to fail back with the loss of one captured and one wounded. The assailing force then approached the reserve post, and on being halted by the officer in command, represented themselves as belonging to the 3d Pennsylvania cavalry, on their way to Bealeton Station.
Finding that their story was discredited, they poured a volley into our men, and immediately retired into the woods to re-load, receiving as they fell back, the fire of our picket reserve.
Our men were somewhat sheltered by breastworks, which were repeatedly and desperately charged by the enemy, who was in every instance repulsed.
The fight continued half an hour, when the rebel force retreated.

Twelve wounded rebels were found on Friday morning at a house half a mile from the scene of the engagement, and three were found dead on the field.
Our loss was but two wounded. The wounded rebels state that the attack was made under the impression that a Government paymaster was present with the Rhode Island cavalry, for the purpose of paying off the men on the 15th inst.

div4.head: The raid in the Northern Neck.
div4.p:
The recent raid in the Northern Neck of Virginia was made by the Yankee garrison guarding the prisoners at Point Lookout, Md. The result of the raid, as reported by the American, was the capture of 25 prisoners, 60 horses, 20 mules, 65 head of cattle, and 100 head of sheep.--The expedition embarked from Point Lookout on the 12th, under command of Brig. Gen. Marston.
It consisted of 300 infantry and 130 men of the 2d and 5th United States cavalry.
During their raid they visited Warsaw, Richmond county Lancaster Court-House, and Little Waltham.
At the first named place they found a large quantity of Government stores, consisting of pork and bacon, which were destroyed.
At Kilmarnock, ten miles from Lancaster Court-House, they destroyed an extensive tannery, and a large stock of leather, oil, hides, machinery, &c.

div4.head: Miscellaneous.
div4.p:
A letter from the blockading fleet off Wilmington announces the loss of the executive officer, I engineer, and 17 men from the Montgomery, and I ensign, the captain's clerk, and 7 men from the Aries, while attempting to take possession of the blockade running steamer Dare, which had been run ashore.
The particulars of the capture have been published in the Richmond papers.
In the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania the motion to dissolve the injunction heretofore granted to restrain the Provost Marshal from taking drafted men was granted.
Hendricks and Hart, two Yankee newspaper correspondents, have reached New York, having been "paroled" for ninety days by the Confederate authorities.

Capt. W. W. White, Provost Marshal of the Eighteenth Pennsylvania District at Williamsport, has been dismisses the service and arrested and lodged in the Old Capitol Prison for alleged frauds in the business of his office.

The Confederate steamer Florida is lying in port at Brest, France, making ready to leave.
She is lying near the U. S. gunboat Kearsage.
Col. Wm. McNeir, for many years official printer to the Maryland Senate, died in Philadelphia on the 17th inst.
A banquet was given to the veterans of the Irish Brigade in New York on the 16th. Gen. Meagher was the principal speaker.
Col. Fish has retired from the post of Provost Marshal of Baltimore and Major Hayner appointed to the post.
Robert J. Walker writes from England that there is a great revolution of opinion there in favor of the Yankees.
A fire occurred in New York on Saturday week destroying property to the amount of $1,250,000.
Gens. Hancock and Burnside are to recruit their old corps to 50,000 men each.
A court-martial has been called for the trial of Surgeon-General Hammond.
Gold was quoted in New York, on the 18th, at 158¼a159.

div3.head: Extract from the Richmond Correspondence of the London Herald.

div4.head: [dated Richmond,January 5th.]
div4.p:
The public papers of this city announced a few days previously, that the President would be glad to receive visits from his friends between 12 and 3 o'clock on New Year's day.
Having gone to the Executive Mansion with the family of my old friend, Hon. Mrs. Henry, a distinguished Senator from Tennessee, I found on my arrival, the steps and halls of that building crowded with fair women and brave men. A charming girl from Louisiana, expelled from her father's roof tree by the barbarous soldiery of Gen. Banks, was my special companion on the occasion; and her presence having quickened into a subdued startle the gallantry for which the well-bred gentlemen of the South are so remarkable, threw over the circle around us a decidedly courtly grace.
The President stood in an elegant room with Mrs. Davis on his left.
His Excellency — for the occasion — was one of state — was dressed in a suit of black; and while appearing in good health, looked rather more careworn than usual.
Soldiers and civilians, males and females, his visitors, having exchanged with him wishes of happiness for the ensuing year, passed on their way to the hall-door; or if they happened to know the officers of the staff or some visitors who were so fortunate, made a circuit for presentation to Mrs. Davis.
That lady is by no means an ordinary woman.
Her style is very much that of the period of George the third--reminding one indeed of the pictures of the wives of the great State officers of the government of George Washington.
She is a stately woman, with brunette complexion, and eyes full of brilliance, tenderness, and intelligence.
Her manners are very agreeable; but touched with a repose that even though carried to almost sadness, savors very much of the grand.
She and the President appeared to be in good spirits, and were regarded by their troops of visitors with a warmth and heartiness that were maintained in perfect harmony with an air of profound respect.

The Provost Marshal General of Mr. Lincoln's dominions has furnished an official report of the working of the Fedral draft.
My anticipation of peace having been predicated on the failure of conscription at the North, an examination of some points of that report may be instructive. "Of those drawn in the present draft," says ol. Fry, the Provost Marshal General of the Northern autocrat, "including the fifty per cent. additional, over eighty per cent. have reported in accordance with the orders of the Boards.
Of the twenty per cent. who have not reported, many are not willful deserters, being unavoidably absent at sea and the like.
The deserters are being arrested.
Of all examined about 30 per cent. have been exempted under the provisions of the second section of the act, or found not liable to military duty on account of alliance, unsuitableness of age, non-residents, &c. * * * about one-half of those held to service have paid commutation; of the remainder about one-thirds have gone in person, and two-thirds have furnished substitutes, and all except a few in transit and a small proportion or deserters from among the earlier substitutes are in the ranks of their regiments in front of the enemy!

The numbers represented in the percentages of Col. Fry's report will present the facts he states in a light more direct for the objects of this review--300,000 men having been the net result sought in the conscription, the number "drawn" was extended, in order to cover contingencies, to fifty per cent. additional--450,000.
The percentages of the report are predicated on that total; and show therefore the following distributions under the several heads:

row.cell: Deserters, &c., the 20 per cent. who did not "report,"
Physically disabled--30 per cent, of remainder,
Aliens, persons of unsuitable age, &c., (30 per cent.
Exempted by commutation,
Exempted by substitution,
Held to service,

div4.p:
There is some reason to suppose that these percentages of Col. Fry's are stated loosely in favor of the "draft" They show an aggregate result to the Federal army of 72,000, whereas Gen. Halleck sets it down in his official report at about $50,000. Col. Fry himself says that the expenses of the conscription, which he states to have been $1,200,000, is about one tenth that of the payments made for "commutation." At $300 in each instance, even taking that proportion fully, his own statement would thus reduce the 72,000 resulting from his percentage in the case to about 40,000.
The figures in the above table may therefore be held considerably in excess of the actual results of the "draft. " The conscription had not, I appears, been carried out in all the States; but only a few members of "the Union" having been omitted in a measure pressed so searchingly, the shortcomings on this account may in all likelihood be held covered by the excess of the forgoing figures.

Three hundred thousand men having been sought for, Col. Fry admits that he obtained but 72,000. --This general fact shows that the last draft was a failure.
The average which I struck in number 22 of these dispatches will have shown, on the faith of the returns in eight districts of Massachusetts, that the breadth of the conscription covered one third of the whole material available at the North for recruitment of her armies.
1,300,000 of the flower of her manhood having been already brought into the field, this exhaustion of her resources in men available for military service is not to be wondered at even though considerations of industrial production had not already come in to establish the fact more forcibly.
Assuming, however, that the draft now spoken of by Mr. Lincoln's agents be carried out to the fullest extent, the experience of last year's conscription shows that it will not yield over 144,000 men.

Industrial considerations appear to forbid the extension of the conscription now proposed to all the manhood fit for military duty within "the Union." The deficit in last year's crop of wheat at the North amounted, it appears, to the enormous quantity of 16,000,000 of bushels.
The resources for substitution may, no withstanding the infamous measures that have been employed for stimulating the emigration of able-bodied Germans and Irishmen, be fairly supposed to have been already largely absorbed.

This fact will increase desertion, and tend further to reduce the actual results of the "draft" by throwing many cases that take place under the head of "substitutions," in the present returns of Col. Fry, under the head of "commutations."--The fact that 90,000 men succeeded in cheating the last conscription of victims by refusing to "report," shows a state of public opinion which, in a thinly settled country, with mountains, forests, and swamps, offers quite as safe a means as commutation or substitution for slipping through the meshes of Mr. Lincoln's net. Reasonable expectation, therefore, may look in the coming "draft" for a large addition to the percentage of the last under the head of those who declined to "report. " Assuming the extension of the conscription now to all that remain available at the North for service in the field, there is, for these reasons, fair grounds for the conclusion that the results of the pending measures for that purpose will fall very far below 114,000.
But may it not be confidently assumed, with the evidence before us of the fact of upwards of half a million of acres of land under one crop having already dropped out of culture, that the proposed "draft" cannot be carried out to any very great extent without overrunning the limit of commissariat necessities — as has already been done in reference to financial exigencies — to the very serious crippling of the resources of labor required for Northern production.

But Col. Fry's figures do not show the working of the "draft" beyond the time when he delivered its victims to Meade's or Rosecrans's officers bound hand and foot.
My dispatch of the 10th of December went into that part of the history of last year's conscription at the point where Col. Fry's returns stop.
In order to follow out the subject in connection with that officer's figures I will repeat here that those conscripts added nothing whatever to the Federal strength.
They dragged through the forms of drill in a spirit of morose mutiny.
They sat over their camp fires in sullen groups away from the older soldiery.
They regarded the volunteers around them with the hate attaching to the instruments of an obnoxious compulsion.
They were never allowed to go outside the rear camp pickets; and were in fact constantly under surveillance or guard.
To prevent their desertion in the hour of battle they were placed in its very front.--Of all this there can be no doubt; and the conclusion is therefore irresistible that the conscription of 1863 added nothing in fact to Mr. Lincoln's strength in the field.

The dogged spirit of last years conscripts was, however, not merely passive.
It took form, naturally, in desertion.
Having been in the Federal rear for nearly two months, up to the end of October, I employed, during that time, frequent opportunities of mingling in the constant stream of conscripts returning without his consent from the army of General Meade.
Of many inquiries, I noted the answers in a dozen cases, and find that of 20 "drafted" men, added on an average to each company, fifteen had deserted successfully, two had been captured in the attempt, and those actually remaining in service-- "in front of the enemy," as Col. Fry will have it — averaged but three!
The breadth of my inquiries satiety me that those figures present a fair of generalization touching the working of the "draft;" and I therefore conclude that, of the 50,000 men which General Halleck says it contributed to the army, the number remaining in the field on the 1st of November last did not exceed eight thousand.
Fewer still may be reasonably supposed to remain there now. On all these considerations I cannot avoid a very decided conviction that the proposed conscription of Mr. Lincoln's subjects will be found, by the opening of his spring campaign, a total failure.
But does he really mean to carry it out?

New England proposes to supply her quote under the new conscription by decoying or forcing able bodied slaves from the peace and comfort of their Southern homes; and thus while gratifying her benevolence, and, still more agreable result, saving her pocket, obtain "soldiers of the Union" without incurring any very heavy bill for "bounties."

This expedient has, however, been already very nearly exhausted; and is, furthermore, tainted with danger of such inconvenient demonstrations as that of the other day at Fort Jackson.
The conscription attempted by the Federalists in "rebellious" districts has resulted in such adverse fortune as the recruitment by Forrest in West Tennessee of eight or ten thousand men. That will consequently do nothing to meet Mr. Lincoln's demand for flesh and blood.
Emigration, is, therefore, as I urged in numbers 30 and 31 of these dispatches, the main channel for furnishing new supplies of victims for the Federal Foo fa fum; and as his dainty stomach prefers, it appears from the letters of his agents in Canada, to taste the blood of those who speak English, the result in that case rests mainly with the Government of a woman of Christian spirit and benevolent heart, Her most gracious Majesty the Queen.
The moral conviction that the youth and manhood of her beloved subjects are being sacrificed under an evasion of law will.
I earnestly hope, prompt that sovereign lady to say to her Ministers:

lg.l: "To do a great good do a little wrong;
And curb this cruel devil of his will."

div4.p:
Bounties will certainly fail to hold, after midsummer much more than one-half of Mr. Lincoln's present armies from civil life.
Volunteering is a thing of the past; conscription a virtual failure!
negro "kidnapping" an expedient already exhausted, and "drafting" in "rebellious" districts cutting both ways; the only means of supplying the deficiencies of next midsummer in the Federal armies lie in emigration.
If Load Palmerston arrest that at once, Mr. Lincoln's small superiority of the present moment in the field will in I probability, end with next July; and with the then probable ascendancy or the South we may, on that supposition, entertain some expectations of peace before autumn.
A desperate effort will however be made in the meantime to overwhelm the Confederates by rapid governments and crushing blows.
The available strength of the South is more than able to meet the whole weight likely to be harried against her in that terrible trial, but to bring it out fully at the approaching crisis of the struggle the country requires a most cheerful and hopeful spirit.
In august last this correspondence examined at length the state of public feeling here, and pointed out the fact that its elasticity appeared to have received a permanent strain under the weight of the disaster at Vicksburg and the miscarriage in Pennsylvania.
The currency soon afterwards became affected, and has now become so heavy that it presses upon the spirit of the people like a load previous to be borne.
The gloom that overshadows the land presents the only doubt which the observer here can entertain touching the breadth and firmness of the front which the Confederates will present next spring to meet the bloody crisis of their conflict for all that is most dear to a gallant and generous people.

The Confederates regard the course of France and England with bitter disappointment.
A sanguine people, they have met in the neutrality of these countries, on which they counted for countenance, a heavy discouragement.
The despondency which rests on them now at the turning point of their fate may be referred to a very great extent to the conviction in the public mind that the great maritime powers, if not hostile to the Confederacy, would have long ago given it the encouragement of recognition.
The direct material results of that act of even handed justice on the part of France and England this public certainly misapprehends; but the consequences of such an act now would, notwithstanding his, work like a spell in swelling the ranks of its army, floating up its currency, filling the storehouses of its commissariat, and infusing into the hearts of its soldier, a fiery enthusiasm that would blast the columns of Grant like sheets of lightning.

Recognition now would undoubtedly be an act of peace.
The crisis of the coming campaign applies forcibly to the North.
If the South maintains her ground resolutely until July or August, then of a surety will the struggle end; and this result may be made a certainty by the enthusiastic spirit that would be aroused amongst this passionate people by announcement of the judgment of Europe in favor of their accomplished independence.
The withholding of recognition now, allowing the Confederates to bring to the rally and to the fight a gloomy spirit and shattered hope will doubtless weaken their souls in the day of deadly trial, and thus resulting in perhaps their disastrous defeat, may enable Grant, with his sword on the arteries of the South at Atlanta, to revive the war spirit of the North in plans of victory.
The struggle will thus have been extended indefinitely; for with their wives, their homes, their lives, all staked upon their success, the Confederates will continue to fight even though driven finally to maintain he contest for years in the fierce spirit of the guerillas of the Spanish Peninsular.
Recognition then, may be held now the only sure harbinger, as it is perhaps the prime condition of an early peace.

The blockade of the Southern ports has, as is I presume known by this time in England, become at last effective.
The Federalists have removed their rights in that case from a basis of mere sufferance, and have finally rested them on the legal footing of "evident danger. " Wilmington is, in fact, the only port now available for the foreign intercourse of the Confederacy.
Even that is being guarded very closely, although you must not accept as by any means true the statement of admiral Lee that but one vessel had passed through the blockading fleet off the approaches to that city for a month — Such a state of things may, however, hold in reference to that port before long.
Indeed, apart from the efficiency of the ships of the enemy, he is said to contemplate an investment of the place by a land force.
In any event, the design of the North to cut the Confederacy into parts by lines of military posts involves for the accomplishment of its object the isolation of those parts from the outside world.
Her wooden vessels enable the North to make the blockade of the ports of the Confederates impassible by merchant ships, and the gravity of that evil, taken in connection with that threatening the division of their country by hostile lines, adds to the gloom that weighs upon their spirits under the disappointment of their hopes of reducing the blockading powers of the North to that of her iron-clad vessels by the appearance off the coast of the long and anxiously expected Confederate rams.

div3.head: The Fort Jackson Emeute.
div3.p:
--The first report of this affair were exaggerated beyond the usual exaggerations which come from the Mississippi.--But there was something in it, although of no great consequence to any one.
The last that we have seen of it in the Northern papers is given as follows in a letter from New Orleans, dated 12th ult., to the Boston Courier:

Our military authorities have just had a foretastes of the wisdom in trusting important military posts to colored troops, by a revolt at Fort Jackson which the newspapers in this department, " by authority," will inform you was "only an altercate a between an officer and some of the men; and soon quieted." I have my information from the lips of the officer in command of that post, the garrison of which consisted of five hundred colored soldiers and officers, and twenty white men, (though some of the colored men are as white as some of their white (officers) and so serious had become the revolt that the officers themselves declared that had they attempted to exercise any authority over their command, every white man would have been gilled, and the negroes have been in possession of the Forts which cost the United States Government so much of life and treasure, and so many months delay to get into our hands.
It has been decided that this regiment of "colored men must be mustered out of the service," in consequence of this situation between an officer and some of the men.

The New York Times has an account of the mutiny at Fort Jackson.
It grew out of Col. Benedict's asking ten negroes coming in from beyond the lines their authority for leaving.
They answered insolently, and be, seizing a whip, commenced lashing them, and a revolt ensued.
One hundred negroes seized loaded guns and fired on the Union troops wildly, most of the shots ranging too high.
No one is reported hurt.
The rioters held possession of the camp all day and night.
The next day moral force prevailed.
The ringleaders were arrested and tried by court-martial.
The writer attaches the blame to Adjutant-General Thomas, whose indiscreet speeches gave the negroes an exalted idea of their position.
An Ohio regiment has been ordered to camp near the fort, to provide against a recurrence of revolt.

div3.head: Capture of Gen. Vance.
div3.p:
--The capture of Gen. Vance, of North Carolina, in East Tennessee, is confirmed.
He was sent to Knoxville.
The following is an account of it from a letter dated Asheville, N. C. January 18:

On Wednesday last, Gen. Vance, with about 150 men entered the village of Savie sville, about 28 miles southeast of Knoxville, and captured a Federal foraging train of seventeen wagons, loaded with flour, &c. He was making his way out in this direction, and on Thursday had reached Cos by's Creek, when about 1 P. M, he was attacked by a regiment of Federal cavalry.
Gen. Vance and about seventy-five men were captured.
The Federals then returned in the direction of Knoxville.--He ordered Col. Thomas, who was some twenty miles distant, to join him with a portion of his command at Cosby; but for some reason his orders were not obeyed.
Henry's cavalry and our artillery passed the same place next day and reached New port safely.
They learned from the citizens that Gen. Vance had been sent to Knoxville.
Major Charles Harris, Conscript Commandant, of Georgia, has ordered carolling officers to furnish the names of all detailed and exempted men who have sole their products at exorbitant rates.

div3.head: From Tennessee.
div3.p: --The Atlanta Intelligencer has advices "from the front" to Thursday night. It says:

q.p:
The indications lead to a suspicion that the enemy meditate a raid upon Rome; but such preparations as will thwart any damage have been completed by our authorities in front.
A large cavalry force is in that region, which will be supported.
The enemy have no pickets this side of Missionary Ridge and not above 10,000 men in Chattanooga, as our scouts, recently returned thence, report.

div3.p: Gen. Mackal is at Falton

We conversed freely with parties recently out from Middle Tennessee.
They state that the inhabitants look with great confidence to the return of our armies by harvest time.
Heavy preparations are being made to receive us. There is less giving way than there was after the retreat from Corinth, because the people have become used to the ebbs and flows of the war, and are not so easily depressed by retrogrades.
The relief of Gen. Bragg was hailed with universal joy, and results are expected under the lead of Johnston.

div3.head: North Carolina troops.
div3.p:
--The troops known as Whitford's Battalion have been organized into a regiment and will hereafter be known as the 67th regiment N. C. troops.
The following are the field officers: Col. John N. Whitford; Lieut-Col. Rufus W. Wharton of 1st Battalion sharpshooters Major Edward Whitford.

The troops commanded by Col. J. W. Hinton, and Major Edwards, in the Chowan country, have been organized into the 68th regiment N. C. troops.
The following are the field officers: Col. James W. Hinton; Lieut. Col. Edward C. Yellowley; Major Joseph J. Edwards.

Lieut-Col. George Wortham, of Granville, has been promoted to the Colonelcy of the 50th regiment, vice J. A. Washington, resigned, and Major John C. Vanhook, of Person, promoted to Lieut. Col. vice Wortham promoted.

Lieut. Col. John E. Brown, of Mecklenburg, has been promoted to Colonel of the 42d regiment N. C. troops, vice Gibbs, resigned, and Major Charles W. Bradshaw, of Davidson, has been promoted to Lieut.-Col. vice Brown promoted.

div3.head: Death of Col. Cluke.
div3.p:
--A dispatch has been received containing information of the death of Col. R. S. Cluke, Acting Brigadier General in Gen. Morgan's command.
This distinguished officer died in the Ohio Penitentiary, in a dungeon, in close confinement.
The news came to Gen. Morgan by letter sent through a flag of truce by Col. D. Howard Smith, now on parole in the city of Columbus, Ohio.

div3.head: Destructive fire at Ashland.
div3.p:
--A most destructive fire occurred on the premises of Mr. Charles Stebbins, at Ashland, about four o'clock on Sunday morning. The alarm proceeded from one of his out houses, and before the flames could be arrested they had spread from one to the other till the whole of them, save his kitchen, had been entirely consumed.
In the stable were one horse, one mule, and several cows, all of which were burnt to death.
In the smoke house Mr. Stebbins had a large lot of bacon, beef, meal, flour, and other provisions, which, with the building, were also a total loss.
It is estimated that the amount of property destroyed by this fire will not fall short of $0,000 or $12,000 Mr. S does not know how the fire originated, but thinks it more than probable that it proceeded from a pile of hot ashes which were thrown immediately in the rear of his stable.

div3.head: Mayor's Court.
div3.p: --The docket in this Court yesterday morning was an unusually long one; but His Honor seemed to be in the humor for work, and was not long in disposing of the cases before him.

The charge against John M. French, of stealing $1,900 in Confederate money from John W. Weeley, on Sunday morning last, was taken up, and witnesses examined.
The complainant, who is a member of the 4th Georgia regiment, testified that he stopped on Saturday night at the Arcade Saloon, and that the accused, with three or four others, lodged in the same room with him. Having slept quite late on Sunday morning, when he awoke the other occupants had gotten up and gone out. Upon getting out of bed he went to a drawer in which he had placed his money, took it out and secreted it under the pillow of his bed. After partially dressing himself, he went into an adjoining room to wash his face and hands, and while in there noticed French walk into the room in which they had slept, which brought to his mind the circumstance of leaving his money there; but, before he could get into the room, he had again gone down the steps.--He immediately went to the head of his bed and lifted up the pillow, and finding that his money was gone, suspicion was immediately directed towards French.
As soon as he could do so, he informed his landlord of what had happened, and together they went in pursuit of the accused, but did not find him. Soon after, however, he returned, and was taken into custody.
Mr. Moran, the proprietor of the "Arcade," substantiated the main facts of the witness's evidence, and as soon as French returned to breakfast went to the watch house after officer Bibb, who came over and arrested him. There being no rebutting testimony, the Mayor remanded the prisoner to the February term of the Hustings Court for trial.

A negro woman, named Fanny, the property of John Cary, was arraigned on the charge of setting fire to the residence of cadmus C. Johnson, some time in December last.
Mr. Johnson suspected Fanny at the time of the occurrence, but preferred waiting till after the expiration of her year with him before taking steps to obtain proof against her. A few days ago he got out a warrant to search her room, and placed it in the hands of officer Davis to execute.
That gentleman did so, and succeeded in finding several articles of wearing apparel belonging to a Mrs. Toddy, the occupant of the room at Mr. Johnson's house in which the fire was first discovered.
There being no doubt of the fact in the mind of Mr. J. that these articles were in Mrs. T.'s room only an hour before the fire occurred, and the whole contents of it being destroyed before the alarm was given, he had no doubt that Fanny stole the articles before applying the torch.-- Johnson described the negro as the worst character he had ever heard of. She had for four months, while with him, harbored a runaway, and stolen things from his family without number.
The Mayor sent her on to the Hustings Court, to answer the charge of arson.

Thomas Mahoney and Joseph Stephens, charged with breaking into and robbing the store of Wm. Holt Richardson, on Saturday night last, of several hundred dollars' worth of ready-made clothing, underwent an examination, and the evidence being of a convincing character His Honor remanded them to prison to answer an indictment before the February term of the Hustings Court.

John Little, an Irishman, was called to answer the charge of stealing two runlets (ten gallons each) of whiskey from Thomas McClarrens, also a native of the "green Emerald Isle. " Little acknowledged that the whiskey had been placed in his charge to take to one of the railroad depots; but that, while he was on his way with it, he was accosted by four men, who shot at him twice and took his charge from him. The story seeming improbable, although Little told it with the utmost candor, His Honor turned the further examination of the case over to the February term of the Hustings Court, and remanded the prisoner to prison.

Witnesses appeared to prove that Richard Steele, charged with receiving Government corn, knowing it to have been stolen, had no knowledge of where it came from, and that he only transferred it from his passage to his store till he could find out who it belonged to. When asked if the corn was for sale, Steele told one of them that it was not — it had been placed in his house by some one without his knowledge or consent, and he had no right to dispose of it. He was therefore discharged.

Martin Quinlan was fined $20 for selling ardent spirits in his house without a license, and required to give $250 security to keep the peace towards Patrick Behan, (whom he had struck,) and all other persons, and good behavior generally for twelve months.

Elizabeth Weluhold was examined on the charge of receiving divers articles of clothing, valued at $120, from some person unknown.
The accusation not being sustained, she was discharged.

Two free negroes, named Rebecca Pittman and Henry Steady, were arraigned on the charge of stealing a lot of clockeryware from Michael Gainsley another negro, and throwing a cabinet belonging to him out of his window.
It being one of those knotty cases which frequently occur among negroes, and in which no one particularly is interested, the Mayor dismissed the whole party, and directed that they should get out of the Court house as soon as possible.

The witness not appearing against Michael Gohen.
charged with stealing $29.50, from Wm. E. Spicer, he was discharged from further prosecution.
A negro woman named Catherine Hill, was ordered twenty lashes, for remaining in the city without proper papers establishing her freedom.
George Banker gave ball in the sum of $1,500 for several violations of the liquor law and to be of good behavior for twelve months.

div3.head: Dr. Leyburn's Lecture.
div3.p:
--The lectures of this gentleman to be delivered to-night, on "Palestine and Jerusalem." will doubtless attract a large audience and prove very instructive and entertaining.
In these days of will, when the mind and heart are surfeited and saddened by the inevitable memories and experiences of battles, campaigns and casualties, it will be a relief to dwell for an hour on these classic and sacred lands.

div3.head: Arrivals at the Libby.
div3.p:
--There were eleven arrivals at the Libby prison yesterday, three officers and eight privates.
The names of the officers are as follows: Capt. Calvin Fuller, of the Virginia militia; Lieut. James H. Thornbury, of the 39th Kentucky regiment, and W. H. Shaw, sheriff of Purnam county, under the jurisdiction of Pierpont.
These parties were all captured in Wayne county, Va.

div3.head: The trial of Fords.
div3.p:
--In Judge Lyons's Court yesterday the trial of Forde was begun in earnest.
The testimony of Messrs. Bowen, Harwood, Quarles, and Godwin, and Dr. Peachy, was taken, but no new facts were developed.
At the conclusion of the examination of the above named witnesses the hour of 4 o'clock arrived, when the Court adjourned till 10 o'clock this morning.

div3.head: Airing the jury.
div3.p: --About five o'clock yesterday afternoon Sergeant Dudley took the jury in the Forde case in charge, and, after forming them into couples, marched them for recreation through some portions of the city, after which they returned to their quarters much refreshed and invigorated.

div3.head: Ca S. District Court.
div3.p:
--No business was transacted in this Court yesterday.
Judge John D. Halyburton, who has been sick for some days, is improving slowly, but will not it is, believed be able to attend to any business this week.

div3.head: Trial postponed.
div3.p:
--The trial of Mrs. Patterson Allan, charged with treasonable correspondence with the enemy, which was set for yesterday, was again postponed.
It has been adjourned over till Monday next.

div3.head: Death of an old citizen.
div3.p: --Mr. Byrd Chamberlayne, an old and highly respected citizen, died in this city yesterday morning at 11 o'clock Mr. C. had been sick for some time.

argument.p: entered according to act of Congress in the year 1863, by J. S. Theasher, in the clerk's office of the District Court of the Confederate States for the Northern District of Georgia.

div3.head: Destruction of a Yankee sloop.
div3.p:
--On the night of the 5th inst., an outward bound sloop, laden with turpentine, while attempting to escape from Pascagoula River, grounded on the bar in Middle Pass.
To prevent her falling into the hands of our pickets, she was fired by her crew, who succeeded in making their escape in small boats.
The vessel and cargo, with the exception of two barrels of turpentine, picked up on the west side of the river, were wholly consumed.
On the evening of the 20th, a gunboat came to under Round Island, and took on board eight or ten negroes who had fled from their owners residing on the river, and carried them to Ship Island.
Yesterday a new gunboat, not seen before in these waters, and three schooners, cutter rigged, were abreast of Horn Island, standing to west ward last night.
This morning several heavy guns were heard in the direction of Chandieur Island.
No gunboat visible to-day.

div3.head: From Gen. Lee's army.
div3.p:
--Lieut. Stringfellow captured on the 22d, between Warrenton and Germantown, Fauquier county, a detachment of five men with the mail of a cavalry brigade.
They also captured the arms, equipments, and horses of the prisoners.
Two prisoners captured by the Prince William cavalry near Bristow Station, on the 20th, were received here to-day.
All quiet in front.

div3.head: From Charleston.
div3.p:
--Seven shots were fired at Sumter yesterday, of which three missed.
The firing on the city continued at long intervals, the shots averaging about one every hour.
Fifteen shells were thrown to-day; no casualties.
The enemy are still busy upon Gregg and the Cumming's Point batteries.
No change reported in the fleet.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 26, Number 22, page 2.

div3.head: Legal tender.
div3.p:
There is a bid before the Senate of Virginia to make Confederate Treasury notes, which are worth at this moment about five cents in the dollar, a legal tender in payment of all debts incurred prior to the secession of the State.
We can hardly bring ourselves to believe the fact.
Nevertheless, it is certainly so, monstrous as it may be.

Let us see how the thing will work.
A man in 1860 buys an estate of a thousand acres, at fifteen dollars an acre, and gives his bond.
Secession takes place, and the law prohibiting the collection of debts during present troubles sets him at ease with regard to his payments.
In the mean time, he happens to have in his possession ten barrels of whiskey, which he can sell at $1,500 a barrel, Confederate money.
He sells this whiskey and with the proceeds pays for the estate.--The money which he pays being worth, at present, about five cents in the dollar, he gets the estate for five hundred dollars; that is to say, for half a dollar an acre, whereas he promised to pay fifteen.
The man who holds the estate has no option.
He must take this money or nothing, for the proposed law makes it a legal tender.
Is it possible that a Virginia Senate can mean to encourage such a fraud as this by giving it the sanction of law?
Yet this is the inevitable consequence of such a law.

The committee who reported this bill, we have no doubt acted with good intentions.--They believed that they were taking an important step in the right direction.
They thought that to make the existing currency a legal tender was to arrest the progress of deprecation.
The slightest recurrence to examples of world wide notoriety would have convinced them of their mistake.--Congress, itself, about one year ago, passed a law equivalent in its operation to a legal tender law. It taxed, in the hands of the holder, all evidences of indebtedness in payment of which he refused to receive the Confederate currency, and that so exorbitantly that in a very few years the tax will consume principal and interest.
This most iniquitous law has inflicted vast injury on many creditors who had already been debarred the privilege of collecting their debts in the usual way, until after the war, and who certainly are as much entitled to the protection of the Legislature as other classes of persons.
But has it had the slightest effect in delaying, even for a moment, the downhill march of the Confederate Treasury notes?
Look at the actual facts of the ease.
This time last year the Confederate currency was about 7 or 8 to one. Three weeks ago it was 20 to one.
This day it is 30 to one, and who can tell what it will be a month hence, if Congress do not arrest it in its precipitate career by stopping Mr. Memminger's machine, and passing stringent laws to compel the funding of outstanding notes?

This was not a new question, even when Congress passed this law. It had been thoroughly tested 170 years before in the then colony of Massachusetts, which issued a number of bills of credit, and after securing, as they thought, their currency at par, by heavy penalties upon those who refused to take them, proceeded to declare them legal tender by law. A great number of persons were swindled out of their just dues, but the law did not arrest the depreciation for a moment.
Every one of the Northern colonies followed the example of Massachusetts, with exactly the same result.
North and South Carolina tried it; but, like the Northern States, they failed altogether to prevent depreciation by penal laws.
In ten different instances, therefore, it had been tried in the colonies, when the Revolution had the folly to try it once more.
And there was the most signal failure of all. The Revolutionary Congress affixed to the refusal to take the continental paper at par the most frightful penalties.
The person so offending was declared to be guilty of treason, was made liable to the punishment of that crime, was declared to be out of the pale of the law. --Yet in a year after the first notes were issued they began to decline.
Seeing this, the Congress passed a law making them a legal tender, when they declined more rapidly than ever.
They fell to ten, twenty, thirty, fifty, one hundred, and a thousand for one, when they expired without a groan.
Let those members of the Senate who desire to vote understandingly on this question, go into the library and get the first volume of Mr. Jefferson's Memoirs and Correspondence.--They will there see the whole matter exposed, and the reason given for the decline.
They will see that the cause was such as could not possibly be reached by making them a legal tender.
It was the very same which has made the Confederate currency not worth much more than the intrinsic value of the paper.
For the first year, when very few bills had been issued, the Continental money was at par. As the necessities of the State required, the issues increased, until the currency became so redundant that Mr. Jefferson says silver and gold, under the like circumstances, would have depreciated.

The very same system was tried in Revolutionary France.
The Convention, when the value of the assignats declined, tried to keep it up by making it legal tender and passing all sorts of sanguinary laws to force its continued circulation.
But they all failed.
Why, then — when this thing has been so often tried without success — why try it again?
We say nothing of the immense depreciation of morals which is sure to follow such laws, and which, in the case of the colonies, is feelingly lamented by their historians.
It is surely not the duty of legislators to tempt the people to act dishonestly, as laws of this character inevitably do.

England has always manifested great wisdom in her financial and commercial laws, except in a very few instances.
The Bank of England suspended specie payment in 1797, and did not resume fully until 1821.
In the interval her notes, at one time, fell to fifteen or twenty per cent discount.
Yet she never dreamed, during that interval, of making them a legal tender, for the all sufficient reason that they were not equal to gold and silver in value — the very reason that is now prompting our Legislature to a contrary course.
At length, in 1834, when the notes of the Bank of England were worth pound for pound and shilling for shilling of gold and silver, an act of Parliament did declare them legal tender, purely as a matter of convenience, and because the receiver could lose nothing by it. The act declared that such notes were to be a legal tender everywhere but at the counter of the bank itself.
If a man present a check there, or a note, and demand specie, the bank is bound to pay it.

div4.p:
On the 19th inst, by the Rev S P Huff.
Mr. Jno L Wallace to Miss Mary Sue black, both of Albemarle.
It his residence, on the 25th instant, of typhoid pneumonia, Byrd Chamberlayne, in the 63d year of his age.
The funeral services will take place from St. James' Church, this afternoon, at 3 o'clock. The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend.
In Atlanta, Ga, on Wednesday, January 20, Mrs Mary F, consort of W A Griffin, and youngest daughter of J B and C P Lankford.

Her friends and acquaintances, and those of Mr. Samuel Tyack and Thus W Keesee, are requested to attend.
Her funeral this morning at 11 o'clock, from the residence of Samuel Tyack, on 2d street, between Broad and Marshall.

Departed this life, on the night of the 24th inst, after a brief but painful illness, Tabitha Bax Ter Peterson, in the 73d year of her age, a native of Charles City county, Va, but for many years a resident of this city, where she was known and respected for her many virtues.
Her funeral will take place from Trinity Church this (Tuesday) afternoon at 3 o'clock. Her friends and acquaintances are invited to attend.
On Monday night, at about 8½ o'clock, Mr Henry Miller, aged 49 years, leaving a large family to mourn his death.
The funeral will take place from St John's (German) Church, on 5th street, Wednesday morning, at 10 o'clock. The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend.
At Camp Winder, on the 9th January, 1864, J W Howle, Company C, 10th Regiment N C Volunteers.
Thus our brave men are falling by the hand of disease, away from friends and loved ones to cheer their last moments.

But for the solace of those dear friends who were denied this privilege, he had the comfort and support of him who sticketh closer than a brother and patiently yielded up his life with the blissful assurance of that life where war's rude alarms never come.
On the 23d of January, at her father's residence, on 24th street, Union Hill, of brain fever Florence Elizabeth, only child of Josephine E, and E L Ziema, aged 14 months and 15 days.

lg.l: He little bed is empty now,
Her clothes are all laid by,
Her darling soul has gone to rest,
For we are all bound to die.

div4.p: In Augusta, Ga., on Wednesday, the 30th December, 1863, Emily Julia, only child of Capt A P, and Mrs Mattle B Boggs, aged six months and 18 days.
In the city of Richmond, on the 14th December, 1863, of consumption, Capt T W Andrews, in the 39th year of his age.

Capt Andrews was a native of Virginia, and was one of the first to leave the home of his adoption, Louisville, Ky, to take up arms in defense of his mother State.
He remained in service until failing health compelled him to retire, and after lingering several months he died respected and esteemed by all who knew him.

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--To remain in or near the city, a likely negro woman, about 34 years of age — She is a good nurse for the sick, a competent servant for all kinds of house work; washes and irons very well, and can turn her hand to cooking.
She is also a good plain seamstress.
Apply to Cary at jail.

div3.head: 30 Slaves for sale privately
div3.p:
--Persons wishing to purchase Slaves are requested to apply by nigger, directed to me at Richmond.
Virginia, or in person, at my office, on Main street, opposite the American Hotel.

div3.head: For Hire
div3.p: --Two good farm hands--one of them is a good driver.
div3.closer:
W G Miller,
Corner Clay and Adams sts. ja 26--3t*

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--A superior cook, washer and ironer.
Also, a dining-room servant, trustworthy and reliable, to remain in the city.
Apply to

div3.head: For Hire
div3.p:
--Two or three men and several house girls.
To good homes they will be put at a low figure Apply to

div3.head: For Hire
div3.p:
--A rough carpenter or shoemaker and warehouse hand.
Also, a good cook and washer, with two children--one two, the other six years old. $100 will command her to a good home.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Williams, Carbington & Barksdale,
13th and Cary streets. ja 23--3t

div3.head: For Hire
div3.p:
--For the rest of the year, a Cook.
He is a man, healthy but not perfectly able bodied; is good at everything except bread making.
will suit well for an eating house.
Terms moderate. --Inquire of
div3.closer:
E Gatewood,
Main st., near 2d. ja 23--3t

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--(To remain in or near the city would be desirable) a very likely Yellow Girl, nineteen years of age. She can cook, wash and iron, and wait in the house or on children.
The owner has no use for her. Apply at Cary street jail.

div3.head: For Hire
div3.p: --A good cook and a good house servant, both servants of good character, and without encumbrance.
div3.closer:
Wm B Johnson,
Grace street, above 8th. ja 21--cod4t*
